The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Amount' means mass per unit area. 'Snow and ice on land' means ice in glaciers, ice caps, ice sheets & shelves, river and lake ice, any other ice on a land surface, such as frozen flood water, and snow lying on such ice or on the land surface.

pflw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
pflw.comment: *where land over land*, i.e., this is the total mass of liquid water contained within the permafrost layer within the land portion of a grid cell divided by the area of the land portion of the cell.

pflw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
pflw.comment: *where land over land*, i.e., this is the total mass of liquid water contained within the permafrost layer within the land portion of a grid cell divided by the area of the land portion of the cell.

prra.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
prra.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.
In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.
In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

sipr.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sipr.comment: mass of liquid precipitation falling onto sea ice divided by grid-cell area

prraIs.comment: Rainfall rate over the ice sheet

prra.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

prra.cell_methods: area: mean where ice_free_sea over sea time: mean
prra.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

prrsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
prrsn.comment: The fraction of the grid averaged rainfall which falls on the snow pack

prsnsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
prsnsn.comment: The fraction of the snowfall which falls on the snow pack

prveg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
prveg.comment: The precipitation flux that is intercepted by the vegetation canopy (if present in model) before reaching the ground.

prveg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
prveg.comment: The precipitation flux that is intercepted by the vegetation canopy (if present in model) before reaching the ground.

qgwr.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
qgwr.comment: Mass flux of water from the soil layer into ground water.

reffcclwtop.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  This is the effective radius 'as seen from space' over convective liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, or for some models it is the sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Reported values are weighted by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.daily data, separated to large-scale clouds, convective clouds. If any of the cloud is from more than one process (i.e. shallow convection), please provide them separately.

reffsclwtop.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  This is the effective radius 'as seen from space' over liquid stratiform cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, or for some models it is the sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Reported values are weighted by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.daily data, separated to large-scale clouds, convective clouds. If any of the cloud is from more than one process (i.e. shallow convection), please provide them separately.

rivi.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rivi.comment: Inflow of River Water into Cell

rivo.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rivo.comment: Outflow of River Water from Cell

rls.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

rlntds.cell_methods: area: mean where ice_free_sea over sea time: mean
rlntds.comment: This is defined as 'where ice_free_sea over sea'

rsdscsdiff.comment: Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations in clear sky conditions
Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations in clear sky conditions

rsdsdiff.comment: Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations.
Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations.
Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations.

rss.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rss.comment: Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface
Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface
Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface

rzwc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rzwc.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The content of a soil layer is the vertical integral of the specified quantity within the layer. The quantity with standard name mass_content_of_water_in_soil_layer_defined_by_root_depth is the vertical integral between the surface and the depth to which plant roots penetrate. A coordinate variable or scalar coordinate variable with standard name root_depth can be used to specify the extent of the layer. 'Water' means water in all phases.

sblnosn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
sblnosn.comment: Rate of sublimation of ice into the atmosphere from areas with no snow.

scldncl.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over stratiform liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

snm.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snm.comment: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.
The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

sndmassmelt.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sndmassmelt.comment: the rate of change of snow mass through melt divided by sea-ice area

snm.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snm.comment: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

snmIs.comment: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

snm.comment: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

snmsl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snmsl.comment: Mass flow rate of water draining out of the snow pack.

snrefr.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snrefr.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Surface snow and ice refreezing flux' means the mass flux of surface  meltwater which refreezes within the snow or firn.

snicefreez.comment: Mass flux of surface meltwater which refreezes within the snowpack. Computed as the total refreezing on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

snicefreezIs.comment: Mass flux of surface meltwater which refreezes within the snowpack. Computed as the total refreezing on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

snicefreez.comment: Mass flux of surface meltwater which refreezes within the snowpack. Computed as the total refreezing on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

snwc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snwc.comment: Total water mass of the snowpack (liquid or frozen), averaged over a grid cell and intercepted by the canopy.

sootsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
sootsn.comment: the entire land portion of the grid cell is considered, with snow soot content set to 0.0 in regions free of snow.

sootsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
sootsn.comment: the entire land portion of the grid cell is considered, with snow soot content set to 0.0 in regions free of snow.

sw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
sw.comment: Total liquid water storage, other than soil, snow or interception storage (i.e. lakes, river channel or depression storage).

t20d.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
t20d.comment: This quantity, sometimes called the 'isotherm depth', is the depth (if it exists) at which the sea water potential temperature equals some specified value. This value should be specified in a scalar coordinate variable. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

t20d.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
t20d.comment: This quantity, sometimes called the 'isotherm depth', is the depth (if it exists) at which the sea water potential temperature equals some specified value. This value should be specified in a scalar coordinate variable. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

tau.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tau.comment: module of the momentum lost by the atmosphere to the surface.

tauupbl.comment: The  downward eastward stress associated with the models parameterization of the planetary boundary layer. (This request is related to a WGNE effort to understand how models parameterize the surface stresses.)

tauvpbl.comment: The  downward northward stress associated with the models parameterization of the planetary boundary layer. (This request is related to a WGNE effort to understand how models parameterize the surface stresses.)

tcs.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tcs.comment: Vegetation temperature, averaged over all vegetation types

tdps.comment: Dew point temperature is the temperature at which a parcel of air reaches saturation upon being cooled at constant pressure and specific humidity.
Dew point temperature is the temperature at which a parcel of air reaches saturation upon being cooled at constant pressure and specific humidity.

tpf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tpf.comment: The mean thickness of the permafrost layer in the land portion of the grid cell.  Reported as zero in permafrost-free regions.

tpf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tpf.comment: The mean thickness of the permafrost layer in the land portion of the grid cell.  Reported as zero in permafrost-free regions.

tran.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tran.comment: Transpiration (may include dew formation as a negative flux).

tran.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tran.comment: Transpiration (may include dew formation as a negative flux).

tsl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tsl.comment: Temperature of soil. Reported as missing for grid cells with no land.

tsl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: point
tsl.comment: Temperature of soil. Reported as missing for grid cells with no land.

tsl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tsl.comment: Temperature of soil. Reported as missing for grid cells with no land.

tsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean (with samples weighted by snow mass)
tsn.comment: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

tsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean (with samples weighted by snow mass)
tsn.comment: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

tsnIs.comment: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

tsn.comment: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

wtd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wtd.comment: Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. The water table is the surface below which the soil is saturated with water such that all pore spaces are filled.

wtd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wtd.comment: Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. The water table is the surface below which the soil is saturated with water such that all pore spaces are filled.

gpp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gpp.comment: The rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers') expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.

gppGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
gppGrass.comment: Total GPP of grass in the grid cell

gppLut.comment: The rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers') expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production. Reported on land-use tiles.

gppShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
gppShrub.comment: Total GPP of shrubs in the grid cell

gppTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
gppTree.comment: Total GPP of trees in the grid cell

gpp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gpp.comment: The rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers') expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.

ra.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
ra.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to autotrophic respiration on land (respiration by producers) [see rh for heterotrophic production]

raGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
raGrass.comment: Total RA of grass in the grid cell

raLut.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to autotrophic respiration on land (respiration by producers) [see rh for heterotrophic production]. Calculated on land-use tiles.

raShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
raShrub.comment: Total RA of shrubs in the grid cell

raTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
raTree.comment: Total RA of trees in the grid cell

ra.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
ra.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to autotrophic respiration on land (respiration by producers) [see rh for heterotrophic production]

rh.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rh.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to heterotrophic respiration on land (respiration by consumers)

rhGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
rhGrass.comment: Total RH of grass in the grid cell

rhLut.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to heterotrophic respiration on land (respiration by consumers), calculated on land-use tiles.

rhShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
rhShrub.comment: Total RH of shrubs in the grid cell

rhTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
rhTree.comment: Total RH of trees in the grid cell

rh.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rh.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to heterotrophic respiration on land (respiration by consumers)

icem.comment: Loss of ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt water on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

icemIs.comment: Loss of ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt water on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

icem.comment: Loss of ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt water on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

mrroLi.comment: Runoff flux over land ice is the difference between any available liquid water in the snowpack less any refreezing. Computed as the sum of rainfall and melt of snow or ice less any refreezing or water retained in the snowpack

Runoff flux over land ice is the difference between any available liquid water in the snowpack less any refreezing. Computed as the sum of rainfall and melt of snow or ice less any refreezing or water retained in the snowpack

snicem.comment: Loss of snow and ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

snicemIs.comment: Loss of snow and ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

snicem.comment: Loss of snow and ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

jo2.comment: Rate of photolysis of molecular oxygen to atomic oxygen (o2 -> o1d+o)

jo3.comment: Sum of photolysis rates o3 -> o1d+o2 and o3 -> o+o2

oxloss.comment: total chemical loss rate for o+o1d+o3

oxprod.comment: total production rate of o+o1d+o3 including o2 photolysis and all o3 producing reactions

sltbasin.cell_methods: longitude: sum (comment: basin sum [along zig-zag grid path]) depth: sum time: mean

tntmp.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

tntmp27.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

tntmp.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

tntnogw.comment: Temperature tendency due to dissipation of parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.

tntogw.comment: Temperature tendency due to dissipation of parameterized orographic gravity waves.

xgwdparam.comment: Parameterised x-component of gravity wave drag
Parameterised x-component of gravity wave drag

ygwdparam.comment: Parameterised y- component of gravity wave drag
Parameterised y- component of gravity wave drag

zmtnt.comment: The diabatic heating rates due to all the processes that may change potential temperature

bry.comment: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Bry = Br + BrO + HOBr + HBr + BrONO2 + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic bromine (e.g., HBr and inorganic bromine oxides and radicals (e.g., BrO, atomic bromine (Br), bromine nitrate (BrONO2)) resulting from degradation of bromine-containing organic source gases (halons, methyl bromide, VSLS), and natural inorganic bromine sources (e.g., volcanoes, sea salt, and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

cly.comment: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Cly = HCl + ClONO2 + HOCl + ClO + Cl + 2*Cl2O2 +2Cl2 + OClO + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic stratospheric chlorine (e.g., HCl, ClO) resulting from degradation of chlorine-containing source gases (CFCs, HCFCs, VSLS), and natural inorganic chlorine sources (e.g., sea salt and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

hcl.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of hydrogen chloride is HCl.
Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of hydrogen chloride is HCl.

hno3.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

ho2.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of hydroperoxyl radical is HO2.

meanage.comment: The mean age of air is defined as the mean time that a stratospheric air mass has been out of contact with the well-mixed troposphere.

noy.comment: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model); list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. NOy = N + NO + NO2 + NO3 + HNO3 + 2N2O5 + HNO4 + ClONO2 + BrONO2 Definition: Total reactive nitrogen; usually includes atomic nitrogen (N), nitric oxide (NO), NO2, nitrogen trioxide (NO3), dinitrogen radical (N2O5), nitric acid (HNO3), peroxynitric acid (HNO4), BrONO2, ClONO2 add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

oh.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

vt100.comment: Zonally averaged eddy temperature flux at 100hPa as monthly means derived from daily (or higher frequency) fields.

mrro.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrro.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

mrro.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrro.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

mrroLut.comment: the total runoff (including 'drainage' through the base of the soil model) leaving the land use tile portion of the grid cell

mrroIs.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

mrro.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrro.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

mrso.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrso.comment: the mass per unit area  (summed over all soil layers) of water in all phases.

mrsoLut.comment: 'Water' means water in all phases. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The mass content of water in soil refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including 'content_of_soil_layer' are used.

mrso.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrso.comment: the mass per unit area  (summed over all soil layers) of water in all phases.

snw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snw.comment: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.

snw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: point
snw.comment: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.

snw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snw.comment: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.

sfdsi.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sfdsi.comment: This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.

sfdsi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sfdsi.comment: This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.

sfdsi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sfdsi.comment: This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.

siage.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)

siareaacrossline.comment: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

siarean.comment: total area of sea ice in the Northern hemisphere

siareas.comment: total area of sea ice in the Southern hemisphere

sicompstren.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sicompstren.comment: Computed strength of the ice pack, defined as the energy (J m-2) dissipated per unit area removed from the ice pack under compression, and assumed proportional to the change in potential energy caused by ridging. For Hibler-type models, this is P (= P*h exp(-C(1-A)) where P* is compressive strength, h ice thickness, A compactness and C strength reduction constant).

sidconcdyn.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidconcdyn.comment: Total change in sea-ice area fraction through dynamics-related processes (advection, divergence...)

sidconcth.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidconcth.comment: Total change in sea-ice area fraction through thermodynamic processes

sidivvel.cell_methods: area: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) time: point
sidivvel.comment: Divergence of sea-ice velocity field (first shear strain invariant)

sidmassdyn.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassdyn.comment: Total change in sea-ice mass through dynamics-related processes (advection,...) divided by grid-cell area

sidmassgrowthbot.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassgrowthbot.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to vertical growth of existing sea ice at its base divided by grid-cell area.

sidmassgrowthwat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassgrowthwat.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to sea ice formation in supercooled water (often through frazil formation) divided by grid-cell area. Together, sidmassgrowthwat and sidmassgrowthbot should give total ice growth

sidmasslat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmasslat.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass through lateral melting divided by grid-cell area (report 0 if not explicitly calculated thermodynamically)

sidmassmeltbot.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassmeltbot.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass through melting at the ice bottom divided by grid-cell area

sidmassmelttop.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassmelttop.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass through melting at the ice surface divided by grid-cell area

sidmasssi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmasssi.comment: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to transformation of snow to sea ice divided by grid-cell area

sidmassth.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sidmassth.comment: Total change in sea-ice mass from thermodynamic processes divided by grid-cell area

sidmasstranx.comment: Includes transport of both sea ice and snow by advection

sidmasstrany.comment: Includes transport of both sea ice and snow by advection

sidragbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sidragbot.comment: Oceanic drag coefficient that is used to calculate the oceanic momentum drag on sea ice

sidragtop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sidragtop.comment: Atmospheric drag coefficient that is used to calculate the atmospheric momentum drag on sea ice

siextentn.comment: Total area of all Northern-Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15 % areal fraction of sea ice

siextents.comment: Total area of all Southern-Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15 % areal fraction of sea ice

sifb.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sifb.comment: Mean height of sea-ice surface (=snow-ice interface when snow covered) above sea level

siflcondbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflcondbot.comment: the net heat conduction flux at the ice base

siflcondtop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflcondtop.comment: the net heat conduction flux at the ice surface

hfsso.cell_methods: area: mean where ice_free_sea over sea time: mean
hfsso.comment: Downward sensible heat flux over sea ice free sea. The surface sensible heat flux, also called turbulent heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air.

siflfwbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflfwbot.comment: Total flux of fresh water from water into sea ice divided by grid-cell area; This flux is negative during ice growth (liquid water mass decreases, hence upward flux of freshwater), positive during ice melt (liquid water mass increases, hence downward flux of freshwater)

fsitherm.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
fsitherm.comment: computed as the sea ice thermodynamic water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.

siflfwdrain.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflfwdrain.comment: Total flux of fresh water from sea-ice surface into underlying ocean. This combines both surface melt water that drains directly into the ocean and the drainage of surface melt pond. By definition, this flux is always positive.

siflsensupbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflsensupbot.comment: the net sensible heat flux under sea ice from the ocean

siflswdbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siflswdbot.comment: The downwelling shortwave flux underneath sea ice (always positive)

siforcecoriolx.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforcecoriolx.comment: X-component of force on sea ice caused by coriolis force

siforcecorioly.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforcecorioly.comment: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by coriolis force

siforceintstrx.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforceintstrx.comment: X-component of force on sea ice caused by internal stress (divergence of sigma)

siforceintstry.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforceintstry.comment: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by internal stress (divergence of sigma)

siforcetiltx.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforcetiltx.comment: X-component of force on sea ice caused by sea-surface tilt

siforcetilty.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
siforcetilty.comment: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by sea-surface tilt

sihc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sihc.comment: Heat content of all ice in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Water at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of snow, but does include heat content of brine. Heat content is always negative, since both the sensible and the latent heat content of ice are less than that of water

simass.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
simass.comment: Total mass of sea ice divided by grid-cell area

simassacrossline.comment: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

simpmass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice_melt_pond (comment: mask=simpconc)

simprefrozen.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice_melt_pond (comment: mask=simpconc)
simprefrozen.comment: Volume of refrozen ice on melt ponds divided by meltpond covered area

sisali.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sisali.comment: Mean sea-ice salinity of all sea ice in grid cell

sisaltmass.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sisaltmass.comment: Total mass of all salt in sea ice divided by grid-cell area

sishevel.cell_methods: area: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) time: point
sishevel.comment: Maximum shear of sea-ice velocity field (second shear strain invariant)

sisnhc.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sisnhc.comment: Heat-content of all snow in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Snow-water equivalent at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of sea ice.

sistremax.cell_methods: area: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) time: point
sistremax.comment: Maximum shear stress in sea ice (second stress invariant)

sistresave.cell_methods: area: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) time: point
sistresave.comment: Average normal stress in sea ice (first stress invariant)

sistrxdtop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sistrxdtop.comment: X-component of atmospheric stress on sea ice

sistrxubot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sistrxubot.comment: X-component of ocean stress on sea ice

sistrydtop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sistrydtop.comment: Y-component of atmospheric stress on sea ice

sistryubot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sistryubot.comment: Y-component of ocean stress on sea ice

sitempbot.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sitempbot.comment: Report temperature at interface, NOT temperature within lowermost model layer

sivoln.comment: total volume of sea ice in the Northern hemisphere

sivols.comment: total volume of sea ice in the Southern hemisphere

sndmassdyn.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sndmassdyn.comment: The rate of change of snow mass through advection with sea ice divided by sea-ice area

sndmasssi.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sndmasssi.comment: the rate of change of snow mass due to transformation of snow to sea ice divided by sea-ice area

sndmasswindrif.cell_methods: area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)
sndmasswindrif.comment: the rate of change of snow mass through wind drift of snow (from sea-ice into the sea) divided by sea-ice area

snmassacrossline.comment: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

c13Land.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c13Land.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).

c13Litter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c13Litter.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

c13Soil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c13Soil.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in soil.

c13Veg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c13Veg.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass).

c14Land.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c14Land.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).

c14Litter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c14Litter.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

c14Soil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c14Soil.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in soil.

c14Veg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
c14Veg.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass).

cLand.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLand.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

cLitterCwd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLitterCwd.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Wood debris' means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent.

cCwd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cCwd.comment: Carbon mass per unit area in woody debris (dead organic matter composed of coarse wood.  It is distinct from litter)

cLitterSubSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLitterSubSurf.comment: subsurface litter pool fed by root inputs.

cLitterBelow.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLitterBelow.comment: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'subsurface litter' means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

cLitterSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLitterSurf.comment: Surface or near-surface litter pool fed by leaf and above-ground litterfall

cLitterAbove.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cLitterAbove.comment: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Surface litter' means the part of the litter resting above the soil surface. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

cMisc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

cOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

cStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

cWood.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
cWood.comment: Carbon mass per unit area in wood, including sapwood and hardwood.

cTotFireLut.comment: Different from LMON this flux should include all fires occurring on the land use tile, including natural, man-made and deforestation fires

fFireAll.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fFireAll.comment: From all sources,  Including natural, anthropogenic and Land-use change. Only total fire emissions can be compared to observations.

clcalipsoice.comment: Percentage cloud cover in CALIPSO standard atmospheric layers.

clcalipsoliq.comment: Percentage liquid water ice cloud cover in CALIPSO standard atmospheric layers.

cldncl.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

climodis.comment: Total ice cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS).

clwmodis.comment: Mass of cloud liquid water, as seen by the  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS). Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

co23D.comment: report 3D field of model simulated atmospheric CO2 mass mixing ration on model levels

conccmcn.comment: includes all particles with diameter larger than 1 micron

conccn.comment: 'Number concentration' means the number of particles or other specified objects per unit volume. 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. 'Ambient_aerosol' means that the aerosol is measured or modelled at the ambient state of pressure, temperature and relative humidity that exists in its immediate environment. 'Ambient aerosol particles' are aerosol particles that have taken up ambient water through hygroscopic growth. The extent of hygroscopic growth depends on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles.

concdust.comment: Mass concentration means mass per unit volume and is used in the construction mass_concentration_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. Aerosol particles take up ambient water (a process known as hygroscopic growth) depending on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles. 'Dry aerosol particles' means aerosol particles without any water uptake.

sconcdust.comment: mass concentration of dust dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

concnmcn.comment: includes all particles with diameter smaller than 3 nm

depdust.comment: Fdry mass deposition rate of dust

diabdrag.comment: Other sub-grid scale/numerical zonal drag excluding that already provided for the parameterized orographic and non-orographic gravity waves. This would be used to calculate the total 'diabatic drag'. Contributions to this additional drag such Rayleigh friction and diffusion that can be calculated from the monthly mean wind fields should not be included, but details (e.g. coefficients) of the friction and/or diffusion used in the model should be provided separately.

ec550aer.comment: Aerosol volume extinction coefficient at 550nm wavelength.
Aerosol volume extinction coefficient at 550nm wavelength.

fBNF.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fBNF.comment: The fixation (uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere) of nitrogen due to biological processes.

fCLandToOcean.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fCLandToOcean.comment: leached carbon etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.

fDeforestToAtmos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fDeforestToAtmos.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fLuc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fLuc.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to human changes to land (excluding forest regrowth) accounting possibly for different time-scales related to fate of the wood, for example.

fDeforestToProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fDeforestToProduct.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fLulccProductLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon primarily through harvesting land use into anthropogenic product pools, e.g.,deforestation or wood harvesting from primary or secondary lands, food harvesting on croplands, harvesting (grazing) by animals on pastures.

fFireNat.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

fHarvestToAtmos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fHarvestToAtmos.comment: any harvested carbon that is assumed to decompose immediately into the atmosphere is reported here

fHarvest.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fHarvest.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area due to crop harvesting

fHarvestToProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fHarvestToProduct.comment: be it food or wood harvest, any carbon that is subsequently stored is reported here

fLitterFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fLitterFire.comment: Required for unambiguous separation of vegetation and soil + litter turnover times, since total fire flux draws from both sources

fLulccAtmLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon directly to the atmosphere due to any land-use or land-cover change activities.  Include carbon transferred due to deforestation or agricultural directly into atmosphere, and  emissions form anthropogenic pools into atmosphere

fLulccResidueLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon into soil or litter pools due to any land use or land-cover change activities

fN2O.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fN2O.comment: Surface upward flux of nitrous oxide (N2O) from vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil.

fNAnthDisturb.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNAnthDisturb.comment: will require some careful definition to make sure we capture everything - any human activity that releases nitrogen from land  instead of into product pool goes here. E.g. Deforestation fire, harvest assumed to decompose straight away, grazing...

fNLandToOcean.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNLandToOcean.comment: leached nitrogen etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.

fNLitterSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNLitterSoil.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil.

fNOx.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNOx.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. 'Nox' means a combination of two radical species containing nitrogen and oxygen NO+NO2. 'Vegetation' means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil.

fNProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNProduct.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fNVegLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNVegLitter.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. 'Vegetation' means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass.

fNVegSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNVegSoil.comment: In some models part of nitrogen (e.g., root exudate) can go directly into the soil pool without entering litter.

fNdep.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

fNfert.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNfert.comment: Total Nitrogen added for cropland fertilisation (artificial and manure). Relative to total land area of a grid cell, not relative to agricultural area

fNgas.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgas.comment: Total flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere.

fNgasFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgasFire.comment: Flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere due to fire

fNgasNonFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgasNonFire.comment: Flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere due to all processes other than fire

fNleach.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNleach.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Leaching' means the loss of water soluble chemical species from soil. Runoff is the liquid water which drains from land. If not specified, 'runoff' refers to the sum of surface runoff and subsurface drainage.

fNloss.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNloss.comment: Not all models split losses into gaseous and leaching

fNnetmin.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNnetmin.comment: Loss of soil nitrogen through remineralization and immobilisation. Remineralization is the degradation of organic matter into inorganic forms of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other micronutrients, which consumes oxygen and releases energy. Immobilisation of nitrogen refers to retention of nitrogen by micro-organisms under certain conditions, making it unavailable for plants.

fNup.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNup.comment: The uptake of nitrogen by fixation: nitrogen fixation means the uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere.

fProductDecomp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fProductDecomp.comment: Flux of CO2 from product pools into the atmosphere. Examples of 'forestry and agricultural products' are paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock. Models that simulate land use changes have one or more pools of carbon that represent these products in order to conserve carbon and allow its eventual release into the atmosphere, for example, when the products decompose in landfill sites.

fProductDecompLut.comment: Flux of CO2 from product pools into the atmosphere. Examples of 'forestry and agricultural products' are paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock. Models that simulate land use changes have one or more pools of carbon that represent these products in order to conserve carbon and allow its eventual release into the atmosphere, for example, when the products decompose in landfill sites. Produce this variable i  a model has explicit anthropogenic product pools by land use tile

fVegFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegFire.comment: Required for unambiguous separation of vegetation and soil + litter turnover times, since total fire flux draws from both sources

fVegLitterMortality.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegLitterMortality.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegLitterSenescence.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegLitterSenescence.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegSoilMortality.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegSoilMortality.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegSoilSenescence.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegSoilSenescence.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fahLut.comment: Anthropogenic heat flux generated from non-renewable human primary energy consumption, including energy use by vehicles, commercial and residential buildings, industry, and power plants.  Primary energy refers to energy in natural resources, fossil and nonfossil, before conversion into other forms, such as electricity.

flandice.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
flandice.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to land ice (runoff water from surface and base of land ice or melt from base of ice shelf or vertical ice front) into the ocean divided by the area ocean portion of the grid cell

flashrate.comment: proposed name: lightning_flash_rate (units to be interpreted as 'counts km-2 s-1)

gppc13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gppc13.comment: The rate of synthesis of carbon-13 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers') expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.

gppc14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gppc14.comment: The rate of synthesis of carbon-14 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers') expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.

intuadse.comment: Vertically integrated eastward dry static energy transport (cp.T +zg).v (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of eastward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)

intuaw.comment: Vertically integrated Eastward moisture transport (Mass weighted vertical integral of the product of eastward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

intvadse.comment: Vertically integrated northward dry static energy transport (cp.T +zg).v (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)

intvaw.comment: Vertically integrated Northward moisture transport (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

irrLut.comment: Mass flux of water due to irrigation.

lwsrfasdust.comment: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover.

lwsrfcsdust.comment: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover. Calculating in clear-sky conditions.

lwtoaasdust.comment: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

lwtoacsaer.comment: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

lwtoacsdust.comment: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover.

md.comment: Emission from a primary source located anywhere within the atmosphere, including at the lower boundary (i.e. the surface of the earth).

emidust.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

mmrno3.comment: Dry mass fraction of nitrate aerosol particles in air.
Dry mass fraction of nitrate aerosol particles in air.

nLand.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLand.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nLeaf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLeaf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area.

nLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitter.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nLitterCwd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterCwd.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Wood debris' means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nLitterSubSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterSubSurf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Subsurface litter' means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nLitterSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterSurf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Surface litter' means the part of the litter resting above the soil surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nMineral.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineral.comment: SUM of ammonium, nitrite, nitrate, etc over all soil layers

nMineralNH4.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineralNH4.comment: SUM of ammonium over all soil layers

nMineralNO3.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineralNO3.comment: SUM of nitrate over all soil layers

nOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nProduct.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nRoot.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nSoil.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nVeg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nVeg.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

necbLut.comment: Computed as npp minus heterotrophic respiration minus fire minus C leaching minus harvesting/clearing. Positive rate is into the land, negative rate is from the land.  Do not include fluxes from anthropogenic product pools to atmosphere

netAtmosLandCO2Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandCO2Flux.comment: Flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).

nbp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nbp.comment: This is the net mass flux of carbon from atmosphere into land, calculated as photosynthesis MINUS the sum of  plant and soil respiration, carbon fluxes from fire, harvest, grazing  and land use change. Positive flux is into the land.

nep.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nep.comment: Natural flux of CO2 (expressed as a mass flux of carbon) from the atmosphere to the land calculated as the difference between uptake associated will photosynthesis and the release of CO2 from the sum of plant and soil respiration and fire.  Positive flux is into the land.  Emissions from natural fires and human ignition fires as calculated by the fire module of the dynamic vegetation model, but excluding any CO2 flux from fire included in fLuc (CO2 Flux to Atmosphere from Land Use Change).

netAtmosLandC13Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandC13Flux.comment: Flux of carbon 31as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).-

netAtmosLandC14Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandC14Flux.comment: Flux of carbon-14 as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).

nppGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
nppGrass.comment: Total NPP of grass in the grid cell

nppLut.comment: 'Production of carbon' means the production of biomass expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. Net primary production is the excess of gross primary production (rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors) by autotrophs ('producers'), for example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton, over the rate at which the autotrophs themselves respire some of this biomass. 'Productivity' means production per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A.

nppShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
nppShrub.comment: Total NPP of shrubs in the grid cell

nppTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
nppTree.comment: Total NPP of trees in the grid cell

npp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
npp.comment: 'Production of carbon' means the production of biomass expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. Net primary production is the excess of gross primary production (rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors) by autotrophs ('producers'), for example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton, over the rate at which the autotrophs themselves respire some of this biomass. 'Productivity' means production per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A.

nppOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nppStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

od443dust.comment: Total aerosol AOD due to dust aerosol at a wavelength of 443 nanometres.

od865dust.comment: Total aerosol AOD due to dust aerosol at a wavelength of 865 nanometres.

od550dust.comment: Total aerosol AOD due to dust aerosol at a wavelength of 550 nanometres.

od550aerso.comment: From tropopause to stratopause as defined by the model

od550so4so.comment: Stratospheric aerosol AOD due to sulfate aerosol at a wavelength of 550 nanometres.

pabigthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
pabigthetao.comment: A passive tracer in an ocean model whose surface flux does not come from the atmosphere but is imposed externally upon the simulated climate system. The surface flux is expressed as a heat flux and converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were a heat flux being added to conservative temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were conservative temperature. The passive tracer is zero in the control climate of the model.

pathetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
pathetao.comment: The quantity with standard name sea_water_added_potential_temperature is a passive tracer in an ocean model whose surface flux does not come from the atmosphere but is imposed externally upon the simulated climate system. The surface flux is expressed as a heat flux and converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were a heat flux being added to potential temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were potential temperature. The passive tracer is zero in the control climate of the model. The passive tracer records added heat, as described for the CMIP6 FAFMIP experiment (doi:10.5194/gmd-9-3993-2016), following earlier ideas. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

pr17O.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain the oxygen-17 isotope (H2 17O), including solid and liquid phases.

pr18O.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain the oxygen-18 isotope (H2 18O), including solid and liquid phases.

pr2h.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain one atom of the hydrogen-2 isotope (1H 2H O), including solid and liquid phases.

prbigthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
prbigthetao.comment: A passive tracer in an ocean model which is subject to an externally imposed perturbative surface heat flux. The passive tracer is initialised to the conservative temperature in the control climate before the perturbation is imposed. Its surface flux is the heat flux from the atmosphere, not including the imposed perturbation, and is converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were being added to conservative temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were conservative temperature.

prsn17O.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain the oxygen-17 isotope (H2 17O), including solid phase only.

prsn18O.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain the oxygen-18 isotope (H2 18O), including solid phase only.

prsn2h.comment: Precipitation mass flux of water molecules that contain one atom of the hydrogen-2 isotope (1H 2H O), including solid phase only.

prthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
prthetao.comment: A passive tracer in an ocean model which is subject to an externally imposed perturbative surface heat flux. The passive tracer is initialised to the potential temperature in the control climate before the perturbation is imposed. Its surface flux is the heat flux from the atmosphere, not including the imposed perturbation, and is converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were being added to potential temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were potential temperature.

prw17O.comment: Water vapor path for water molecules that contain oxygen-17 (H2 17O)

prw18O.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
prw18O.comment: Water vapor path for water molecules that contain oxygen-18 (H2 18O)

prw2H.comment: Water vapor path for water molecules that contain one atom of the hydrogen-2 isotope (1H 2H O)

raLeaf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

raOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

raRoot.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
raRoot.comment: Total autotrophic respiration from all belowground plant parts.  This has benchmarking value because the sum of Rh and root respiration can be compared to observations of total soil respiration.

raStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

rac13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rac13.comment: Flux of carbon-13 into the atmosphere due to plant respiration. Plant respiration is the sum of respiration by parts of plants both above and below the soil. It is assumed that all the respired carbon dioxide is emitted to the atmosphere.

rac14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rac14.comment: Flux of carbon-14 into the atmosphere due to plant respiration. Plant respiration is the sum of respiration by parts of plants both above and below the soil. It is assumed that all the respired carbon dioxide is emitted to the atmosphere.

rhLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhLitter.comment: Needed to calculate litter bulk turnover time. Includes respiration from CWD as well.

rhSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhSoil.comment: Needed to calculate soil bulk turnover time

rhc13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhc13.comment: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ('consumers'), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ('producers') do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.

rhc14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhc14.comment: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ('consumers'), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ('producers') do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.

sconcso4.comment: mass concentration of sulfate dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer.

sconcss.comment: mass concentration of sea-salt dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

sedustCI.comment: Dry mass deposition rate of dust aerosol.

sw17O.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sw17O.comment: Ratio of abundance of oxygen-17 (17O) atoms to oxygen-16 (16O) atoms in sea water

sw18O.comment: Ratio of abundance of oxygen-18 (18O) atoms to oxygen-16 (16O) atoms in sea water

sw2H.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
sw2H.comment: Ratio of abundance of hydrogen-2 (2H) atoms to hydrogen-1 (1H) atoms in sea water

sweLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'lwe' means liquid water equivalent. 'Amount' means mass per unit area. The construction lwe_thickness_of_X_amount or _content means the vertical extent of a layer of liquid water having the same mass per unit area. Surface amount refers to the amount on the ground, excluding that on the plant or vegetation canopy.

swsrfasdust.comment: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover.

swsrfcsdust.comment: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover. Calculated in clear-sky conditions.

swtoaasdust.comment: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

swtoacsdust.comment: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

tSoilPools.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tSoilPools.comment: defined as 1/(turnover time) for each soil pool. Use the same pools reported under cSoilPools

thetaot.comment: Vertical average of the sea water potential temperature through the whole ocean depth

thetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
thetao.comment: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field.

thetaoga.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
thetaoga.comment: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field

thetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
thetao.comment: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field.

thetaoga.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
thetaoga.comment: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field

twap.comment: Product of air temperature and pressure tendency

uqint.comment: Column integrated eastward wind times specific humidity

ut.comment: Product of air temperature and eastward wind

vqint.comment: Column integrated northward wind times specific humidity

vt.comment: Product of air temperature and northward wind

vtendogw.comment: Tendency of the northward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.  (Note that CF name tables only have a general northward tendency for all gravity waves, and we need it separated by type.)

wetlandCH4.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wetlandCH4.comment: Net upward flux of methane (NH4) from wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).

wetlandCH4cons.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wetlandCH4cons.comment: Biological consumption (methanotrophy) of methane (NH4) by wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).

wetlandCH4prod.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
